description:

7.5/10 on IMDB
89% on Rotten Tomatoes
name: Inside Llewyn Davis

description:
René  Magritte was a Belgian surrealist artist, the Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium has the world’s largest collection of his work, it displays some 200 original Magritte paintings, drawings and sculptures. Come to visit the permanent collection with us! The entrance is 8 euros (and the usual reduced rates is 2 euros). 

If you want to find more about the museum here is the website : http://www.musee-magritte-museum.be/

I'm looking forward to visit it with you!

The Women's Cultural Club Brussels

I you have any question do not hesitate to contact me at [masked]
how_to_find_us: I'll be in front of the entrance with a beige duffle coat, I'll be there at 13h50.
name: Magritte Museum Visite

description:
THE BODY IN INDIAN ART

"Whether its yoga, ayurveda or kamasutra - no civilization has had quite as fascinating an understanding of the body as India. This exhibition takes one on a journey from death to rebirth, from the controlling forces of fate to the power of human action, from desire and seduction to its conquest via asceticism. Come and discover a rapturous display of masterpieces of Indian art from ancient temples, tiny provincial museums, royal collections and treasures from the National Museum of India, many of which have never been seen before".


You can find more information on the following link:http://www.bozar.be/activity.php?id=13021&;;

I'm looking forward to meet you! If you have any question or suggestion feel free to contact me at [masked], your thoughts are more than welcome!

Prices:
€ 14,00: full price
€ 11,00: BOZARfriends / over 65 / ICOM
€ 8,00: students / jobseekers / under 26
€ 4,00: under 12
€ 1,00: schools
Free access: children under 6
name: Exhibition: The Body in Indian Art

description:
"The Blue Route
This exhibition follows the footsteps of the Silk Road through the colour blue, for centuries inspiring artists, craftsmen and poets, both in the East and West alike.
From the Mediterranean to China, this imaginary journey evokes the indigo of textiles, the blue ceramics of the Ottoman Empire and Central Asia, turquoise and lapis-lazuli jewels, culminating with the famous China blue.
The exhibition invites visitors on a journey through space and time, through cultures and art described in its diverse forms of expression. More than forty modern and contemporary artists have been invited for this exhibition, which will subsequently be shown to the public in the Museum of Limoges.
While blue was regarded as a barbaric colour in Greek and Roman Antiquity, the East already used it in art as well as in everyday life, be it for religious rituals, dyeing textiles, decorating ceramics and glass, or the ornamentation of precious jewellery.
Known as anil, indigo gave its name to the Nile, the blue river of Egypt, where the colour was thought to bring good fortune in the afterlife. Turquoise was dedicated to Hathor, goddess of motherhood, and the god Horus pectoral is of a deep blue, symbolizing the healing eye as well as the sun.
In Persia, it was thought that the world rested on a sapphire giving the sky its radiance, while in ancient China blue was attributed the medicinal properties of the indigo plant and was used in the manufacture of paper, clothes and porcelain. The Tibetans, for their part, treasured turquoises as a charm protecting water and springs.

If the East has long regarded blue as endowed with certain virtues, curiously it was not until the 12th century that Europe gradually appreciated the colour, which hitherto had only been described in a poor language. But since more modern times, Blue has found its rightful place in the West, to the point of becoming, ahead of red and green the worlds favourite colour, symbolizing dreams, wisdom and serenity. Henceforth, blue is ubiquitous: associated with the purity of water, the infinity of the heavens and seas, divine and royal right, work clothes and jeans of all generations, the works of Impressionist and Fauve artists to those of Matisse and Yves Klein. Blue is colour adorned with many attributes and there are countless expressions that give meaning to its thousands of shades".

Alongside works by major artists such as
Pierre Alechinsky, Yves Klein and Joan Miró

Prices
Standard admission price: 10 €
7 € per person for groups of 8 or more
8 € per person (students, teacher and for 65s)
name: BOGHOSSIAN FOUNDATION

description:
Tim Porter is a Canadian photographer, he has travelled and photographed extensively in Japan and parts of
Asia, India and the South Pacific. This is the openning of his exhibition regarding his work in Tokyo. You can find more information about his work and the gallery on the following links:
http://www.tim-porter.com/
http://tokyo-gardens.com/
http://www.galeriedidierdevillez.be/expo.php
http://www.galeriedidierdevillez.be/pdf/Invitporter.pdf
name: Tim Porter, a Canadian in Tokyo

description:
From 25th January to 2nd February
Brafa takes place in the large halls of the mail sorting station of “Thurn & Taxis” The exhibition space comprises a total surface of[masked] m², spread over room 1, 2, 3 and 4 of the building A. This historical building, located along the Willebroek canal, is a wonderful example of the Belgian industrial architectural heritage. It was built around[masked] according to the plans of the architect Van Humbeek and was originally used as a storage place for transit merchandise. Technically seen it is the most astonishing building of the site, covered by a phenomenal metal frame of[masked] m². The complex is situated in the heart of Brussels, only a few minutes from Place Rogier, the North Station and the tube station Yser.

Admission:
Individual: 20 €
Groups (≥ 10 pers.): 10 € per person
≤ 26 years: 10 €
≤ 12 years: free
Check the website to know the exhibitors and do the vistual tour!
http://www.brafa.be/DesktopDefault.aspx?tabid=1
name: Exhibition: BRAFA 2014
